data.title: Who Is The Most Famous Clark In The World?
data.meta_description: The Who Is The Most Famous Clark In The World?, as voted on by fans. Current Top 3: Clark Gregg, Clark Datchler, Clark Griffith
data.text:
Voting Rules

Vote up all of the Clarks you've heard of.

How many celebrities named Clark can you think of? The famous Clarks below have many different professions, including notable actors named Clark, famous athletes named Clark, and even musicians named Clark.

Clark Gable is certainly one of the most famous Clarks on this list. One of the famous actors named Clark, he won an Oscar for his role in It Happened One Night. Gone with the Wind, Test Pilot, and Red Dust are among his notable projects.

Another of the famous people with the first name Clark is Clark Gregg. He is an actor best known for playing Agent Phil Coulson in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. He previously played Mike Casper in The West Wing and Richard in The New Adventures of Old Christine.

Did we forget one of your favorite famous people named Clark? Just add them to the list!

Latest additions: Clark L. Ruffner

Help shape these rankings by voting on this list of Who Is The Most Famous Clark In The World?

Ranked by

Birthplace : Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Robert Clark Gregg (born April 2, 1962) is an American actor, director, screenwriter, and voice actor. He plays Agent Phil Coulson in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, beginning in Iron Man (2008) and continuing through Iron Man 2 (2010), Thor (2011), The Avengers (2012), Captain Marvel (2019), and the television series Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. since 2013, making him the actor with the longest screen time in the MCU. Clark Gregg also portrays Sarge in the show's sixth season and an L.M.D. Coulson in the show's fourth, sixth and seventh seasons. He also voices the character on the animated television series Ultimate Spider-Man and in the video games Lego Marvel Super Heroes, Lego Marvel Avengers, and Marvel Heroes. Gregg has also co-starred as Christine Campbell's ex-husband Richard in the CBS sitcom The New Adventures of Old Christine, which debuted in March 2006 and concluded in May 2010. He also played FBI Special Agent Mike Casper on the NBC series The West Wing and Cam, the on-and-off boyfriend of Jack (and client of Grace), on the NBC sitcom Will & Grace.

2

Clark Datchler

03/27/1964

Birthplace : Sutton, London, United Kingdom

Clark Wynford Datchler (born 27 March 1964) is an English singer, songwriter, musician and record producer. He first rose to fame in 1987 as the lead singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist in the band Johnny Hates Jazz.

Birthplace : Clear Creek Township, Cooper County, Missouri, Missouri

Clark Calvin Griffith (November 20, 1869 – October 27, 1955), nicknamed "The Old Fox", was an American Major League Baseball (MLB) pitcher, manager and team owner. He began his MLB playing career with the St. Louis Browns (1891), Boston Reds (1891), and Chicago Colts/Orphans (1893–1900). He then served as player-manager for the Chicago White Stockings (1901–1902) and New York Highlanders (1903–1907). He retired as a player after the 1907 season, remaining manager of the Highlanders in 1908. He managed the Cincinnati Reds (1909–1911) and Washington Senators (1912–1920), making some appearances as a player with both teams. He owned the Senators from 1920 until his death in 1955. Sometimes known for being a thrifty executive, Griffith is also remembered for attracting talented players from the National League to play for the Senators when the American League was in its infancy. Griffith was elected to the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1946.

Birthplace : Cadiz, Ohio, USA

Clark Gable, born on February 1, 1901, in Cadiz, Ohio, is an enduring icon of classic American cinema, best known for his role as Rhett Butler in the timeless epic Gone with the Wind. An embodiment of Hollywood's "Golden Age," Gable's magnetic performances and unmistakable charisma solidified his place in film history. His life off-screen, marked by personal tragedy and resilience, mirrored the complexity of the characters he so masterfully portrayed. Raised in a working-class family, Gable's journey to stardom was anything but conventional. After dropping out of high school, he worked a series of odd jobs before pursuing a career in theater. It wasn't until the late 1920s that he made his way to Hollywood, where he quickly ascended to leading-man status with his breakout role in The Painted Desert (1931). His rugged charm, good looks, and distinctive voice captivated audiences, making him one of the most sought-after actors of his era. Despite his successful career, Gable faced numerous personal struggles, including the heartbreaking loss of his third wife, actress Carole Lombard, in a plane crash. Throughout his career, Gable took on a range of roles that showcased his versatility as an actor. From romantic leads in films like Mogambo (1953) to hard-bitten heroes in war dramas such as Command Decision (1948), his performances often reflected the grit and determination that characterized his own life. Gable's final screen appearance was in the western The Misfits (1961), alongside Marilyn Monroe. The legendary actor passed away later that same year, leaving behind an inimitable legacy in Hollywood. To this day, Clark Gable remains a symbol of classic American cinema, his life and work continuing to inspire new generations of actors and filmmakers.

Birthplace : Atlanta, Georgia

Clark Howell Woodward (March 4, 1877 – May 29, 1967) served the United States Navy in five wars: the Spanish–American War, Philippine–American War, the Chinese Boxer Rebellion, and both World Wars. A staunch promoter of an advanced U.S. Navy, he influenced priorities and policies concerning the upgrading and construction of modern naval warships. Upon his retirement after fifty years and six months of active duty, he assured an audience at Annapolis that "the first fifty years were the hardest."

Birthplace : Stony Creek, Pennsylvania

Clark Kerr was an American professor of economics and academic administrator. He was the first chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, and twelfth president of the University of California.
